thread.title: Tom Watson performs cheeky 'dab' during PMQs after Corbyn blasts May
thread.title_full: Tom Watson performs cheeky 'dab' during PMQs after Corbyn blasts May

author: Mark Molloy
title: Tom Watson performs cheeky 'dab' during PMQs after Corbyn blasts May
text:
Tom Watson performs cheeky 'dab' during PMQs after Corbyn blasts May Tom Watson dabs during PMQs Credit: Twitter Mark Molloy 22 February 2017 • 1:17pm 
T om Watson surprised political spectators after appearing to pull off a dab dance move during Prime Minister’s Questions . 
Labour's deputy leader joined in the with dab craze, a gesture which involves raising one arm and hiding your face as if you are about to sneeze, after Jeremy Corbyn attacked Theresa May over the NHS. Big question: Did @tom_watson dab at the end of Jeremy Corbyn's PMQs? pic.twitter.com/i3VRVGKRFo — Jim Waterson (@jimwaterson) February 22, 2017 Was Tom Watson's #pmqs dab the first on the floor of the Commons? Is there a rule against them? Should there be?! https://t.co/6dAGwzrvLm — Carl Dinnen (@carldinnen) February 22, 2017 @carldinnen Well that's a fantastic use of "Labour source". — Jim Waterson (@jimwaterson) February 22, 2017 Tom Watson can't resist a cheeky dab after Jeremy Corbyn's blast at Theresa May on the NHS #PMQs pic.twitter.com/TFtIe6FKlf — Asa Bennett (@asabenn) February 22, 2017 
“Big question: Did @tom_watson dab at the end of Jeremy Corbyn's PMQs?” asked Jim Waterson. 
W hile Carl Dinnen tweeted: “Was Tom Watson's #pmqs dab the first on the floor of the Commons? Is there a rule against them? Should there be?!” 
Dinnen added that a Labour source had confirmed Watson did ‘dab’ at the end of PMQs. He joked it was “possibly the most hip hop thing that has ever happened at #PMQs”. — Laurie Beth (@Laurie_Beth) February 22, 2017 
C orbyn claimed nine out of 10 NHS trusts are "unsafe" during an attack on the Government's record which prompted his deputy to do the dab. 
The Labour leader said the Conservative administration has put the NHS and social care in a "state of emergency", adding that a government that invests in the health service is needed. 
Mrs May accused Labour of replacing "boom and bust" with "borrow and bankrupt". Follow Telegraph News
